name: Tokyo
fun_fact: Tokyo has more Michelin-starred restaurants (212) than any other city in the world—yet its most beloved local dish, monjayaki, has never earned a single star. This gooey, runny pancake was originally called 'mojiyaki' (grilled letters) because children in the Tsukishima neighborhood would practice writing characters in the batter before eating it!

historical_evolution.summary: From humble fishing village Edo to world's largest metropolis in 260 years

periods.name: Fishing Village
periods.description: Small fishing settlement called Edo at the head of Tokyo Bay

periods.name: Edo Period
periods.description: Tokugawa shogunate transforms Edo into world's largest city (1M+ population). Birth of yatai street food culture feeding bachelor workers. The 'Four Kings of Edo' emerge: soba, eel, tempura, sushi.

periods.name: Meiji to WWII
periods.description: Renamed Tokyo ('Eastern Capital'). Meat ban lifted—sukiyaki born in Asakusa. Kissaten coffee culture emerges. City destroyed twice: 1923 earthquake and WWII bombing.

periods.name: Modern Tokyo
periods.description: Post-war reconstruction. Hoppy invented (1948) as affordable beer alternative. Conveyor belt sushi invented (1950s). Becomes world's most Michelin-starred city.

hero_dishes.name: Monjayaki
hero_dishes.description: Runny savory pancake cooked on iron griddle, eaten with tiny metal spatulas. Originated in Tsukishima where 75+ restaurants line 'Monja Street'.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Children practiced writing letters in the gooey batter—originally called 'mojiyaki' (grilled letters)

hero_dishes.name: Fukagawa Meshi
hero_dishes.description: Hearty clam rice bowl with miso broth and leeks. Fast food for Edo-period fishermen working the clam beds near the Sumida River mouth.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Ranked among Japan's top 5 regional rice dishes, unchanged since the 1700s

hero_dishes.name: Chanko Nabe
hero_dishes.description: Protein-rich hot pot—the diet of sumo wrestlers. Contains fish or chicken with seasonal vegetables in savory broth.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Born in Ryogoku sumo stables during Meiji era. Many restaurants run by retired wrestlers.

hero_dishes.name: Edomae Tempura
hero_dishes.description: Tokyo-style tempura fried in sesame oil blend (not plain vegetable oil like Kyoto), served with mentsuyu dipping sauce.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Heavier sesame flavor developed to complement Tokyo Bay's richer seafood

signature_drinks.name: Hoppy
signature_drinks.description: Beer-flavored low-alcohol drink mixed with shochu. Working-class Tokyo invention from 1948 post-war era.
signature_drinks.how_to_drink: Pour 'Soto' (Hoppy) and 'Naka' (shochu) yourself to adjust strength

signature_drinks.name: Melon Cream Soda
signature_drinks.description: Electric green melon soda with vanilla ice cream scoop and maraschino cherry. Icon of Showa-era kissaten coffee shops.
signature_drinks.origin_story: Invented at Shiseido Parlour in Ginza—Japan's first soda fountain inside a pharmacy

signature_drinks.name: Lemon Chuhai
signature_drinks.description: Shochu mixed with soda and fresh lemon. The ubiquitous izakaya refresher.
signature_drinks.how_to_drink: Best enjoyed under red lanterns in Omoide Yokocho's narrow alleys

food_culture_notes: Omoide Yokocho ('Memory Lane', aka 'Piss Alley') - narrow alleys of tiny yakitori stalls near Shinjuku
Yatai street stall culture born here—feeding Edo's 1.5:1 male population who couldn't cook
Tsukishima's Monja Street has 75+ monjayaki restaurants in one neighborhood
Ryogoku district near Sumo Stadium is chanko nabe central
